page.title: 01Ness Glen and Loch Doon Dam
page.content: At the Northern end of the five mile long Loch doon, a dam, rebuilt in 1933 to provide storage for hydro-electric scheme, controls the flow of the river Doon which has carved a course for itself northwards between magnificent 100 foot high granite cliffs, known as the Ness Glen. Above the head of this glen stands the house of Craigengillan sheltered by variegated woodlands, which was the home of one of the branches of the McAdam family. Behind these woods the grassy moor land stretches away to the South and to the west with scattered burns and hill lochs to the encircling plantations of Carrick Forest, which has been replanted by the Forestry Commission since the days when it provided a hiding place for Robert the Bruce.
